review.title: DR-ABC: Approximate Bayesian Computation with Kernel-Based Distribution Regression
review.abstract: Performing exact posterior inference in complex generative models is often difficult or impossible due to an expensive to evaluate or intractable likelihood function. Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) is an inference framework that constructs an approximation to the true likelihood based on the similarity between the observed and simulated data as measured by a predefined set of summary statistics. Although the choice of appropriate problem-specific summary statistics crucially influences the quality of the likelihood approximation and hence also the quality of the posterior sample in ABC, there are only few principled general-purpose approaches to the selection or construction of such summary statistics. In this paper, we develop a novel framework for this task using kernel-based distribution regression. We model the functional relationship between data distributions and the optimal choice (with respect to a loss function) of summary statistics using kernel-based distribution regression. We show that our approach can be implemented in a computationally and statistically efficient way using the random Fourier features framework for large-scale kernel learning. In addition to that, our framework shows superior performance when compared to related methods on toy and real-world problems.

sections.heading: 2. Related Work
sections.text: Most existing methods for selecting or constructing informative summary statistics can be grouped into three categories. A first category collects methods that first have the best subset in a set of candidate statistics, and then use that subset as summary statistics within ABC statistics. (The second category consists of methods that construct summary statistics from auxiliary models (Joyce & Marjoram, 2008), entropy (Nunes & Balding, 2010), and AIC / BIC (Blum et al., 2013), an example of this approach is the indirect evaluation of ABC (Gleim & Pigorsch, 2013). sections.heading: 4. Experimental Results
sections.text: The first problem we are examining is the following hierarchical model of Gaussian, for which we apply the complete ABC statistics. In this model, the parameter of interest is ABC, and our goal is to estimate the number of data observed. In our experiments, we compare our two methods, complete and conditional DR-ABC, against SA-ABC and K2-ABC. We specifically compare our framework against these methods, as they are examples of the illustration of regression and the RKHS approach to the construction of summary statistics. We calculate the mean square error (MSE) of the parameters of interest in synthetic data. Specifically, we present a series of 200 observations on these parameters as a y value; for each newly simulated dataset, we also draw 200 data points.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we developed a novel framework for constructing informative problem-specific summary statistics using the flexible and expressive environment for reproducing Hilbert core spaces. We introduced two different approaches based on the embedding of probability distributions and nuclear-based distribution regression. Our proposed framework has several advantages over previous generic and semi-automatic summary statistical construction methods. First, by using the flexible RKHS framework, we are able to regulate the type and amount of information extracted from the data and thus construct more informative problem-specific summary statistics, as opposed to an ad-hoc selection of a limited number of candidate statistics or the postulation of heuristic summary statistics, which inevitably result in a difficult-to-evaluate approximation distortion in the probability and subsequently in the subordinate sample.
